London]] |primeminister5 = [[Gordon Brown]] |term_start5 = 5 June 2009 |term_end5 = 11 May 2010 |predecessor5 = [[Tony McNulty]] |successor5 = [[Gavin Barwell]] {{small|(2016)}} |primeminister6 = [[Gordon Brown]] |term_start6 = 28 June 2007 |term_end6 = 3 October 2008 |predecessor6 = [[Jim Fitzpatrick (politician)|Jim Fitzpatrick]] |successor6 = [[Tony McNulty]] |office7 = [[Paymaster General]] |primeminister7 = [[Gordon Brown]] |term_start7 = 28 June 2007 |term_end7 = 11 May 2010 |predecessor7 = [[Dawn Primarolo]] |successor7 = [[Francis Maude]] |office8 = [[Minister for the Olympics]] |primeminister8 = {{Ubl|[[Tony Blair]]|[[Gordon Brown]]}} |term_start8 = 6 July 2005 |term_end8 = 11 May 2010 |predecessor8 = Position established |successor8 = [[Jeremy Hunt]] |office9 = [[Minister for Women and Equalities|Minister for Women]] |primeminister9 = [[Tony Blair]] |term_start9 = 5 May 2005 |term_end9 = 5 May 2006 |predecessor9 = [[Patricia Hewitt]] |successor9 = [[Ruth Kelly]] {{Collapsed infobox section end}} {{Collapsed infobox section begin|Cabinet position (2001–07)}} |office10 = [[Secretary of State for Culture, Media and Sport|Secretary of State for Culture,
Media and Sport]] |primeminister10 = [[Tony Blair]] |term_start10 = 8 June 2001 |term_end10 = 27 June 2007 |predecessor10 = [[Chris Smith, Baron Smith of Finsbury|Chris Smith]] |successor10 = [[James Purnell]] {{Collapsed infobox section end}} {{Collapsed infobox section begin|Shadow position (1995–96)}} |office11 = [[Shadow Minister for Women and Equalities|Shadow Minister for Women]] |leader11 = [[Tony Blair]] |term_start11 = 19 October 1995 |term_end11 = 26 July 1996 |predecessor11 = [[Clare Short]] |successor11 = [[Janet Anderson]] {{Collapsed infobox section end}} |office12 = [[Member of Parliament (UK)|Member of Parliament]]
for [[Dulwich and West Norwood (UK Parliament constituency)|Dulwich and West Norwood]]
{{small|[[Dulwich (UK Parliament constituency)|Dulwich]] (1992–1997)}} |term_start12 = 9 April 1992 |term_end12 = 30 March 2015 |predecessor12 = [[Gerald Bowden]] |successor12 = [[Helen Hayes (politician)|Helen Hayes]] |office13 = [[Members of the House of Lords|Member]] of the [[House of Lords]]
{{small|[[Lord Temporal]]}} |term_start13 = 27 October 2015 |term_end13 = 12 May 2018
[[Life peer]]age |birth_name = Tessa Jane Helen Douglas Palmer |birth_date = {{birth date|1947|9|17|df=y}} |birth_place = [[Marylebone]], London, England |death_date = {{Death date and age|df=yes|2018|5|12|1947|9|17}} |death_place = [[Shipston-on-Stour]], [[Warwickshire]], England |party = [[Labour Party (UK)|Labour]] |spouse = {{ubl|{{marriage|[[Roger Jowell]]
|1970|1977|end=divorced}}|{{marriage|[[David Mills (lawyer)|David Mills]]
|17 March 1979|12 May 2018}}}} |children = 2 |relations = [[Ella Woodward]] {{nowrap|(daughter-in-law)}} |alma_mater = {{Ubl|[[University of Aberdeen]]|[[University of Edinburgh]]|[[Goldsmiths, University of London|University of London]]}} }} '''Tessa Jane Helen Douglas Jowell, Baroness Jowell''', {{post-nominals|country=GBR|size=100%|DBE|PC|sep=,}} ({{nee|'''Palmer'''}}; 17 September 1947 – 12 May 2018) was a British [[Labour Party (UK)|Labour]] politician who was the [[Member of Parliament (UK)|Member of Parliament]] (MP) for [[Dulwich and West Norwood (UK Parliament constituency)|Dulwich and West Norwood]] from 1997 to 2015, having previously been elected as the MP for [[Dulwich (UK Parliament constituency)|Dulwich]] in 1992. She held a number of major government ministerial positions, as well as opposition appointments, during this period. Her most senior position in Government was as Secretary of State for Culture, Media and Sport, a post she held from 2001 to 2007. A member of both the [[Blair ministry|Blair]] and [[Brown ministry|Brown]] Cabinets, she was also [[Minister for the Olympics]] (2005–10) and [[Official Opposition Shadow Cabinet (United Kingdom)|Shadow Minister for the Olympics]] and [[Official Opposition Shadow Cabinet (United Kingdom)|Shadow Minister for London]] until September 2012, resigning after the London Olympic Games. A [[Privy Council of the United Kingdom|Privy Counsellor]] since 1998,{{cite web|publisher=Privy Council Office|title=Privy Counsellors|url=https://privycouncil.independent.gov.uk/privy-council/privy-council-members/privy-counsellors|accessdate=1 June 2016}} she was appointed Dame Commander of the [[Order of the British Empire]] (DBE) in 2012.{{London Gazette |issue=60173 |date=16 June 2012|page=6|supp=y}} She stood down from the [[House of Commons of the United Kingdom|House of Commons]] at the [[United Kingdom general election, 2015|2015 general election]]. She was nominated for [[life peer]]age in the [[2015 Dissolution Honours]] and was raised to the peerage as Baroness Jowell, of [[Brixton]] in the London Borough of [[Lambeth]], on 27 October 2015. In September 2015, she was unsuccessful in seeking to be selected as the Labour Party's official candidate in the [[London mayoral election, 2016]], coming second to [[Sadiq Khan]] in the contest of six candidates. ==Early life== Tessa Jane Helen Douglas Palmer was born at [[Middlesex Hospital]]{{cite web|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/obituaries/tessa-jowell-dead-cancer-brain-tumour-london-olympics-2012-labour-party-age-a8349256.html|title=Remembering Dame Tessa Jowell, the Labour politician who helped to secure the 2012 London Olympics|date=13 May 2018|publisher=}}{{cite news|last=Castle|first=Stephen|date=20 July 1997|title=Profile: Tessa Jowell – Healthy respect for sense|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/voices/profile-tessa-jowell--healthy-respect-for-sense-1251706.html|newspaper=[[The Independent]]|access-date=11 April 2015}} in [[Marylebone]], London, to Dr. Kenneth Nelson Veysey Palmer,{{cite web|url=http://munksroll.rcplondon.ac.uk/Biography/Details/3427|title=Munks Roll Details for Kenneth Nelson Vesey Palmer|website=munksroll.rcplondon.ac.uk}} a [[physician]], and his wife, Rosemary (née Douglas),{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2018/may/13/the-people-politician-tessa-jowell-obituary|title=The 'people politician': Tessa Jowell obituary|first=Julia|last=Langdon|date=13 May 2018|website=the Guardian}}{{cite web|url=http://www.heraldscotland.com/opinion/16222333.Obituary_-_Tessa_Jowell__Labour_politician_who_played_pivotal_role_in_bringing_the_Olympics_to_London/|title=Obituary – Tessa Jowell, Labour politician who played pivotal role in bringing the Olympics to London|website=HeraldScotland}} a [[Radiologic technologist|radiographer]].Profile in ''[[The Observer]]'' by Martin Bright, 22 February 2009 She was educated at the independent [[St Margaret's School for Girls]] in Aberdeen, the [[University of Aberdeen]] (where she studied arts, psychology and sociology) and the [[University of Edinburgh]] (where she studied for an [[Master of Arts|MA]] in Social Administration). She became a social worker, initially working in the [[Craigmillar]] area of Edinburgh and as a childcare officer in [[Lambeth]], before training at [[Goldsmiths College]] as a psychiatric social worker. She subsequently worked at the [[Maudsley Hospital]], and later became assistant director of the mental health charity [[Mind (charity)|Mind]]. During this time, Jowell took her first steps into electoral politics, being elected to represent [[Swiss Cottage (ward)|Swiss Cottage]] on [[Camden London Borough Council]] in the early 1970s, and becoming Chair of the Camden Borough Council's Social Services Committee at the age of 25. In 1978, she was the Labour Party candidate in [[Ilford North by-election, 1978|a by-election]] in [[Ilford North (UK Parliament constituency)|Ilford North]] but lost Labour's majority to the [[Conservative Party (UK)|Conservatives]]. She stood again in Ilford North at the [[United Kingdom general election, 1979|1979 general election]], also unsuccessfully.{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/general-election-2015/11472449/Why-Im-standing-down-from-Parliament-Dame-Tessa-Jowell-MP-for-Dulwich-and-West-Norwood.html|title=Why I’m standing down from Parliament: Dame Tessa Jowell, MP for Dulwich and West Norwood Telegraph|accessdate= 4 May 2015}} ==Member of Parliament== Elected as MP for [[Dulwich (UK Parliament constituency)|Dulwich]] at the [[United Kingdom general election, 1992|1992 general election]],{{cite news |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/politics/class-of-92-to-cut-teeth-in-whips-office-1445334.html | title=Class of '92 to cut teeth in whips' office |first=Patricia |last=Wynn Davies |work=The Independent |date=28 October 1994 |accessdate=13 May 2018}} Jowell was successively appointed as an Opposition Spokesperson on Health, an Opposition [[whip (politics)|Whip]] and Spokesperson on Women,{{cite news |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/harman-i-wont-quit-over-school-1325289.html |title=Harman: I won't quit over school |first=Donald |last=Macintyre |work=The Independent |date=23 January 1996|accessdate=13 May 2018}}{{cite news |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/bring-me-the-women-of-middle-england-1330192.html | title=Bring me the women of middle England |first=Sally |last=Williams |work=Vanity Fair |date=23 July 1996 |accessdate=14 May 2018}} before returning to the Shadow Health team in 1996.{{cite news |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/nhs-opens-hospital-doors-to-insurance-firms-1313164.html |title=NHS opens hospital doors to insurance firms |first=Colin |last=Brown |work=The Independent |date=6 December 1996 |accessdate=14 May 2018}} After boundary changes, she was the MP for [[Dulwich and West Norwood (UK Parliament constituency)|Dulwich and West Norwood]] from 1997. ===In Government=== Jowell was appointed as Minister of State in the [[Department of Health (United Kingdom)|Department of Health]] after the [[United Kingdom general election, 1997|1997 Labour electoral landslide]].{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/home-news/jowell-to-be-britains-first-guardian-of-public-health-1260126.html|title=Jowell to be Britain's first guardian of public health|first=Fran|last=Abrams|work=The Independent|date=6 May 1997|accessdate=13 May 2018}} She moved, again as Minister of State, to the [[Department for Education and Employment]] in 1999.{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/politics/1999/oct/12/reshuffle1999.politicalnews1|title=Younger generation on the move|first=Ewen|last=MacAskill|work=The Guardian|date=12 October 1999|accessdate=13 May 2018}} [[File:Tessa Jowell, 2000.jpg|thumb|upright|left|Jowell in 2000]] She was appointed [[Secretary of State for Culture, Media and Sport|Secretary of State]] at the [[Department for Culture, Media and Sport]] after the [[United Kingdom general election, 2001|2001 election]], replacing the sacked [[Chris Smith, Baron Smith of Finsbury|Chris Smith]].{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2001/jun/11/mondaymediasection.generalelection|title=Welcome to the ministry of fun, Tessa|first=Maggie|last=Brown|work=The Guardian|date=11 June 2001|accessdate=13 May 2018}} One of her main concerns as [[Culture Secretary]] was television broadcasting. She blocked the [[BBC]]'s plans for the digital channel [[BBC Three|BBC3]], on the grounds that they were insufficiently different from commercial offerings, and imposed extra conditions{{cite news|date=5 December 2002|publisher=[[BBC News]]|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/entertainment/2545327.stm|title=BBC news channel told to change|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081228090215/http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/entertainment/2545327.stm |archivedate=28 December 2008|deadurl=yes}} on [[BBC News 24]] after it was criticized on the same grounds by the Lambert Report.{{Cite journal|last=Lambert|first=Richard|year=2002|title=Independent review of BBC News 24|publisher=Dept. for Culture, Media and Sport|url=http://www.culture.gov.uk/NR/rdonlyres/012A7C1A-C9ED-4F5B-8420-5684AE5AA1A7/0/independentreviewnews24.pdf|format=[[Portable Document Format|PDF]]|oclc=52120057|postscript={{inconsistent citations}}|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060311045102/http://www.culture.gov.uk/NR/rdonlyres/012A7C1A-C9ED-4F5B-8420-5684AE5AA1A7/0/independentreviewnews24.pdf|archivedate=11 March 2006}} She was responsible for the [[Communications Act 2003]] which established a new media regulator, [[OFCOM]].{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2001/jul/10/communicationsact.broadcasting|title=Jowell issues warning on digital services|first=Jason|last=Deans|work=The Guardian|date=10 July 2001|accessdate=13 May 2018}}{{Cite news|url=https://theconversation.com/tessa-jowells-farsighted-vision-for-media-literacy-was-ahead-of-its-time-96686|title=Tessa Jowell’s farsighted vision for media literacy was ahead of its time|last=Wallis|first=Richard|work=The Conversation|access-date=2018-08-16|language=en}} It also relaxed regulations on ownership of British television stations, though, following a rebellion in the [[House of Lords]], a 'public interest' test was introduced as a compromise.{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2003/jul/02/ofcom.broadcasting |title=The importance of the public interest |first=Chris |last=Tryhorn |work=The Guardian |date=2 July 2003 |accessdate=13 May 2018}} In July 2003, she launched an overhaul of the [[National Lottery (United Kingdom)|National Lottery]].{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/society/2003/jul/03/lottery.politics1|title=Lottery shakeup unveiled|first=Tash|last=Shifrin|work=The Guardian|date=3 July 2003|accessdate=13 May 2018}} She dealt with complaints that the lottery had been directed to fund programmes that should have been covered by mainstream taxation. In 2001 [[Arts Council England]] announced changes to how funding would be distributed and she supported this.{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2001/jul/16/2 |title=Arts Council restructure will empower the regions |work=The Guardian |date=16 July 2001 |accessdate=13 May 2018}} She oversaw the restructuring of the Arts funding system but lost out in the 2004/5 spending round, when there was a cut in her departmental budget.{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2004/dec/16/arts.artsfunding |title=Arts Council lying over £30m cut in funding, says minister |first=Charlotte |last=Higgins |work=The Guardian |date=16 December 2004 |accessdate=13 May 2018}} In 2004 a tax loophole was closed around film production in Britain.{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/3513442.stm |title=Jowell enticing Bollywood to UK |work=BBC News |date=15 March 2004 |accessdate=13 May 2018}} In 2004, Jowell faced resistance to proposals for a series of so-called "super casinos", to be sanctioned as part of the [[Gambling Act 2005]] which liberalised Britain's [[gaming laws]]. Although [[problem gambling]] has ruined the lives of many ordinary people,{{cite news|last=MacErlean|first=Neasa|date=14 July 2012|title=The problem with gambling: New figures show more people than ever are ruining their lives|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/money/spend-save/the-problem-with-gambling-new-figures-show-more-people-than-ever-are-ruining-their-lives-7942230.html|newspaper=[[The Independent]]|accessdate=13 May 2018}} in the run up to the Bill, Jowell dismissed much of the criticism as being elitist, commenting that "opponents of the Government's gambling reforms are [[snob]]s who want to deny ordinary people the right to bet". Former Labour Welfare Minister [[Frank Field (British politician)|Frank Field]] said her comments were crass, declaring, "I think this whole [[New Labour]] line that you insult people rather than engage in argument is deeply disturbing".{{cite news|last=Kite|first=Melissa|date=24 October 2004|title='Opponents of new gambling law are snobs', says Tessa Jowell|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/1474933/Opponents-of-new-gambling-law-are-snobs-says-Tessa-Jowell.html|newspaper=[[The Daily Telegraph]]}} In March 2005, Jowell announced a new governance system for the BBC: the BBC Trust, to replace the long-established Board of Governors.{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2005/mar/02/bbc.broadcasting1|title=BBC governors to be scrapped|first1=Owen|last1=Gibson|first2=Tara|last2=Conlan|work=The Guardian|date=2 March 2005|accessdate=13 May 2018}} The trust was introduced in 2007 but in 2012 was shown to be 'not fit for purpose', leading to the resignation of the Director General.{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/tvandradio/bbc/9699031/The-BBC-can-get-out-of-this-hole.html|location=London, UK|work=The Daily Telegraph|first=Greg|last=Dyke|title=The BBC can get out of this hole|date=23 November 2012|archivedate=24 November 2012|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121124173417/http://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/tvandradio/bbc/9699031/The-BBC-can-get-out-of-this-hole.html|deadurl=yes}}[[BBC#cite note-34]] In Gordon Brown's [[reshuffle]] in June 2007, following his succession as Labour leader and [[Prime Minister]], Jowell was demoted from her position as [[Secretary of State for Culture, Media and Sport]]. She retained her Olympics portfolio, however, and was also appointed [[Paymaster General]] and [[Minister for London]], being allowed to attend Cabinet, although not as a full member.{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/society/2007/jun/28/publicservices.politics |title=Brown appoints first female home secretary |first=Deborah |last=Summers |work=The Guardian |date=28 June 2007 |accessdate=13 May 2018}} She was further demoted on 3 October 2008, losing her Minister for London role to [[Tony McNulty]], and being allowed to attend cabinet only when her area of responsibility was on the agenda.{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk_politics/7651229.stm |title=In full: Reshuffle changes |work=BBC News |date=6 October 2008 |accessdate=13 May 2018}} In his 2009 reshuffle, Brown reappointed her to the Cabinet as [[Minister for the Cabinet Office]].{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2009/jun/05/gordon-brown-new-cabinet-list|title=Who's who in Gordon Brown's government?|work=The Guardian|date=9 June 2009|accessdate=15 June 2012}} In the 2012 Birthday Honours, Jowell was appointed [[Dame Commander of the Order of the British Empire]] (DBE) for "political and charitable services", in particular for her contribution to delivering the London 2012 Olympics.{{London Gazette|issue=60173|supp=y|page=6|date=16 June 2012}}{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-18440832|title=Tess Jowell: DBE|accessdate=15 June 2012|work=BBC News Online|date=15 June 2012|archivedate=16 June 2012|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120616110252/http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-18440832|deadurl=no}} ===Political positions=== Jowell was a zealous supporter of the then Prime Minister [[Tony Blair]], reportedly saying on one occasion that she would "jump under a bus" for him.{{cite news|title=Time for Jowell to jump may be near|newspaper=[[The Daily Telegraph]]|date=28 February 2006|last=Tweedie|first=Neil|location=London, UK|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/1511666/Time-for-Jowell-to-jump-may-be-near.html|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121112162313/http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/1511666/Time-for-Jowell-to-jump-may-be-near.html|archivedate=12 November 2012|deadurl=yes}}{{cite news|title=Profile: Tessa Jowell: A loyalist to the bitter end|publisher=''[[The Guardian]]''|work=The Observer|location=London, UK|url=https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2009/feb/22/profile-tessa-jowell-david-mills|last=Bright|first=Martin|date=22 February 2009|archivedate=1 March 2009|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090301190650/http://www.guardian.co.uk/politics/2009/feb/22/profile-tessa-jowell-david-mills|deadurl=no}} She was very supportive of [[New Labour]] and was fully loyal to its agenda, earning herself a strong reputation as a [[Blairite]]. In 2007, she supported [[Hazel Blears]] for the deputy leadership of the Labour Party.{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2007/may/17/labourdeputy.labour1|title=Hazel Blears's backers|work=The Guardian|date=17 May 2007|accessdate=13 May 2018}} In 2009, she was mentioned as a possible Cabinet minister who might resign over the leadership of [[Gordon Brown]] in order to trigger a leadership contest – a suggestion which proved unfounded. In opposition, Jowell supported [[David Miliband]]'s campaign to become Leader of the Labour Party,{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2010/may/16/ed-miliband-stands-against-david-miliband|title=Ed Miliband stands against brother David in fight for Labour leadership|first1=Polly|last1=Curtis|first2=Matthew|last2=Taylor|work=The Guardian|date=16 May 2010|accessdate=13 May 2018}} but served in [[Ed Miliband]]'s Shadow Cabinet when he became Leader of HM Opposition.{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-11499638|title=Ex-Home Secretary Johnson is named shadow chancellor|work=BBC News|date=8 October 2010|accessdate=13 May 2018}} In 2010 she briefly appeared as a landmark on [[Google Maps]], as a result of a prank.{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-london-10637726 |title=MP Tessa Jowell becomes a landmark on Google Maps |work=BBC News |date=14 July 2010 |accessdate=13 May 2018}} She was involved in the [[Blue Labour]] movement in the [[Labour Party (UK)|Labour Party]], and was a contributor to ''[[Purple Labour|The Purple Book]]'', drawing on her background on the [[right-wing|Right]] of the Labour Party.{{cite news|url=https://www.thirdsector.co.uk/tessa-jowell-calls-community-led-commissioning/governance/article/1094186|title=Tessa Jowell calls for 'community-led commissioning'|first=John|last=Plummer|work=[[Third Sector (magazine)|Third Sector]]|date=22 September 2011|accessdate=13 May 2018}} Jowell set up the [[Sure Start]] programme, Jowell said, "I am very proud of setting up Sure Start [the national nurture and childcare programme], because the first three years of a child’s life are absolutely critical in determining the chances they have subsequently."[https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2015/apr/26/tessa-jowell-proud-setting-up-sure-start "Tessa Jowell: ‘I’m most proud of setting up Sure Start"], ''[[The Guardian]]'', 26 April 2015. ===London 2012 Olympics=== Jowell was in charge of London's successful bid to host the [[2012 Olympics]]. She came up with the idea in 2002, during her time as Culture Secretary, when she said there was very little support from within the Cabinet, with many colleagues thinking that Paris' bid would win. Jowell convinced the Government to support the bid, however, and went ahead with it.{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-19179711|title=Who's who: Political credit from London Olympics |first=Chris|last=Mason|work=BBC News|date=9 August 2012|accessdate=13 May 2018}}{{cite news |url=https://www.vanityfair.com/culture/2012/06/international-olympic-committee-london-summer-olympics | title=Jumping Through Hoops |first= Michael Joseph |last=Gross |work=[[Vanity Fair (magazine)|Vanity Fair]] |date=9 May 2012 |accessdate=13 May 2018}} In 2004, she launched the bid and, when the Games were awarded to London, she was appointed Olympics Minister (in addition to her responsibilities as Culture Secretary), and held full ministerial responsibility for the bid from 2006. Despite being moved from the Department for Culture, Media and Sport in 2007, she retained her position as Olympics Minister throughout Labour's time in office.{{Cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/obituaries/tessa-jowell-dead-cancer-brain-tumour-london-olympics-2012-labour-party-age-a8349256.html|title=Remembering Dame Tessa Jowell, the Labour politician who helped to secure the 2012 London Olympics|date=2018-05-13|work=The Independent|access-date=2018-05-14|language=en-GB}} Following the general election of May 2010, at which Labour lost power, she became Shadow Olympics Minister. She remained on the 2012 Olympics Organising Committee, with [[Sebastian Coe|Lord Coe]] and [[Jeremy Hunt (politician)|Jeremy Hunt]]. She was appointed [[Deputy Mayor]] of the [[East Village, Stratford|Olympics Village]],{{cite news |url=http://www.newhamrecorder.co.uk/news/london-2012-tessa-jowell-takes-virtual-ride-through-east-village-1-1460375 |title=London 2012: Tessa Jowell takes virtual ride through East Village |first=Sarah |last=Shaffi |work=Newham Recorder |date=26 July 2012 |accessdate=13 May 2018}} being responsible for making the Olympics take place. She resigned her role as Shadow Minister for the Olympics in September 2012, and returned to the [[House of Commons of the United Kingdom|House of Commons]] [[backbench]]es.{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-london-19558488|title=Shadow Olympics Minister Tessa Jowell steps down|work=BBC News|date=11 September 2012|accessdate=13 May 2018}} ==After the House of Commons== In November 2013, Jowell announced that she would not contest the [[United Kingdom general election, 2015|next general election]].{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/av/uk-politics-25045930/tessa-jowell-to-stand-down-as-mp-at-next-election|title=Tessa Jowell to stand down as MP at next election|work=BBC News|date=21 November 2013|accessdate=13 May 2018}} In May 2015, she launched her campaign to be selected as the Labour Party's official candidate in the [[2016 election for Mayor of London]].{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/davehillblog/2015/may/19/tessa-jowell-launches-mayoral-bid-with-one-london-mission-theme|title=Tessa Jowell launches mayoral bid with 'One London' mission theme|first=Dave|last=Hill|work=The Guardian|date=19 May 2015|accessdate=13 May 2018}} Six candidates stood for selection and in September the process concluded with her coming second to [[Sadiq Khan]].{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-34218390|title=Sadiq Khan wins Labour mayoral selection|work=[[BBC News]]|date=11 September 2015|accessdate=11 September 2015}} Had she been elected as [[Mayor of London|Mayor]] she would have died in office almost exactly half way into her term. She was nominated for [[life peer]]age in the [[2015 Dissolution Honours]] by the Labour leader.{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-34076465|title=Full list of new peers and other honours|work=BBC News|date=27 August 2015|accessdate=13 May 2018}} She was raised to the peerage as Baroness Jowell of Brixton in the London Borough of [[Lambeth]], on 27 October 2015.{{London Gazette|issue=61396|date=2 November 2015|page=21422}} In January 2018, Jowell got a standing ovation in the House of Lords for a speech. She began by speaking of how she came to be diagnosed with an extremely lethal form of [[brain cancer]] called [[glioblastoma multiforme]]. She went on to advocate making more cancer treatments available in the [[National Health Service|NHS]]. She said, "In the end, what gives a life meaning is not only how it is lived, but how it draws to a close. I hope that this debate will give hope to other cancer patients, like me, so that we can live well together with cancer, not just dying of it. All of us, for longer."{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/politics/video/2018/jan/25/tessa-jowell-former-labour-mp-delivers-moving-speech-on-brain-cancer-diagnosis-video|title=Tessa Jowell: former Labour MP delivers moving speech on brain cancer diagnosis – video|work=The Guardian|date=25 January 2018|accessdate=13 May 2018}} ==Controversies== ===Jowell, Mills and Berlusconi=== {{main|David Mills financial allegations}} Jowell's husband [[David Mills (lawyer)|David Mills]] was an international corporate lawyer who has acted for [[Silvio Berlusconi]], then the [[Italian Prime Minister]]. Mills was investigated in Italy for [[money laundering]] and alleged [[Tax avoidance and tax evasion|tax fraud]].{{cite news|title=How Jowell's husband played host to Berlusconi at the Garrick Club|author=Richard Owen and Sam Coates|date=22 February 2006|newspaper=[[The Times]]|location=London, UK|registration=yes |url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/politics/article733486.ece|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080211171713/http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/politics/article733486.ece|archivedate=11 February 2008|deadurl=yes}}{{cite news|date=22 February 2006|title=Jowell has nothing to do with Italian bribe allegations, insists her husband|newspaper='The Daily Telegraph|accessdate=30 March 2014|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/europe/italy/1511137/Jowell-has-nothing-to-do-with-Italian-bribe-allegations-insists-her-husband.html|first1=Neil|last1=Tweedie|first2=Hilary|last2=Clarke|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090531090815/http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/europe/italy/1511137/Jowell-has-nothing-to-do-with-Italian-bribe-allegations-insists-her-husband.html|archivedate=31 May 2009|location=London, UK|deadurl=yes}} Jowell was investigated by the [[Cabinet Secretary]] [[Gus O'Donnell]] over the allegations surrounding her husband, because of a possible conflict of interest between her personal life and ministerial duties. O'Donnell stated that, "it is the Prime Minister, not me, who, constitutionally, is the right and proper person to take a view on matters arising based on the [[Ministerial Code]]" in his letter,{{cite news|date=2 March 2006|newspaper=BBC News|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk_politics/4766978.stm|title=In Full: Tessa Jowell inquiry letter|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090221091247/http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk_politics/4766978.stm|archivedate=21 February 2009|deadurl=yes}} and [[Tony Blair]] decided that she was "not in breach" of the ministers' code of conduct.{{cite news |work=BBC News|date=2 March 2006|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/politics/4761194.stm|title=Blair clears Jowell of wrongdoing|archivedate=12 August 2011|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110812162158/http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/politics/4761194.stm|deadurl=no}} On 4 March 2006, it was announced that Jowell and Mills had separated, after the allegations had begun to damage her political standing. Jowell said "although we are separated I have never doubted his innocence".{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/politics/jowellgate-italian-judge-will-press-charges-over-bribery-allegations-468294.html|newspaper=[[The Independent on Sunday]]|title=Jowellgate: Italian judge will press charges over bribery allegations|date=2 March 2006|location=London, UK|first1=Peter|last1=Popham|first2=Colin|last2=Brown|first3=Matthew|last3=Beard|accessdate=25 May 2010|archivedate=31 May 2009|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090531082049/http://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/politics/jowellgate-italian-judge-will-press-charges-over-bribery-allegations-468294.html|deadurl=yes}} Skepticism that Jowell was unaware of the details of her husband's dealings with Berlusconi led to a ''[[Private Eye]]'' front cover of her with a speech bubble saying: "I have never met my husband".Michael Day: ''Being Berlusconi: The Rise and Fall from Cosa Nostra to Bunga Bunga'', St Martin's Press, 2015 Mills allegedly admitted to being "an idiot", and has expressed his remorse about the impact of his dealings upon his wife. The separation had effectively ended by September 2012.{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/politics/labour/9552112/Dame-Tessa-Jowell-reconciles-with-husband-David-Mills.html|work=The Daily Telegraph|title=Dame Tessa Jowell reconciles with husband David Mills|date=19 September 2012|accessdate=14 December 2014|location=London, UK}} On 17 February 2009, an Italian court sentenced Mills to four years and six months in jail after finding him guilty of accepting a bribe from Berlusconi to give false evidence on his behalf during corruption trials which had taken place in 1997 and 1998. His defence counsel said that the sentence went "against the logic and dynamic of the evidence presented". The judgment was appealed by Mills. On 27 October 2009, the Italian Appeal Court upheld his conviction and prison sentence. Mills confirmed that he would initiate a second and final appeal to the Cassation Court.{{cite news|title=Italian judges reject Mills appeal|url=http://www.ft.com/cms/s/9ecf5d56-c362-11de-8eca-00144feab49a,Authorised=false.html?_i_location=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.ft.com%2Fcms%2Fs%2F0%2F9ecf5d56-c362-11de-8eca-00144feab49a.html&_i_referer=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.ft.com%2Fcms%2Fs%2F9ecf5d56-c362-11de-8eca-00144feab49a.html|newspaper=''[[Financial Times]]''|subscription=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121020092324/http://www.ft.com/cms/s/9ecf5d56-c362-11de-8eca-00144feab49a,Authorised=false.html?_i_location=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.ft.com%2Fcms%2Fs%2F0%2F9ecf5d56-c362-11de-8eca-00144feab49a.html&_i_referer=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.ft.com%2Fcms%2Fs%2F9ecf5d56-c362-11de-8eca-00144feab49a.html|archivedate=20 October 2012|author=Guy Dinmore|deadurl=yes}} On 25 February 2010, the Italian Cassation Court (the second and last [[court of appeal]] under Italian law) dissolved the case because of the [[statute of limitations]].{{cite news|publisher=BBC|date=25 February 2010 |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/8535837.stm|title=David Mills bribery conviction quashed by appeals court|accessdate=27 February 2010|archivedate=1 March 2010|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100301043609/http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/8535837.stm|deadurl=yes}}{{cite news|newspaper=[[The Irish Times]]|accessdate=22 August 2010|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/world/2010/0227/1224265274391.html|title=Mills decision a boost for Berlusconi|date=27 February 2010|archivedate=29 October 2010|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101029050315/http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/world/2010/0227/1224265274391.html|deadurl=yes}} For this type of crime, in Italian law, a case expires after 10 years. Mills argued that he received the money in 1999, and not 2000 as Prosecutors had previously argued, thus taking advantage of the statute of limitations.According to the prosecutor the crime occurred on 11 November 1999, when "Mills, on his own, and not as manager of the interests of others, provided instructions for the transfer of about $ 600,000 from the Janus Capital Fund and the Torrey Fund" and February 29, 2000 when the money was actually made available, as is determined by the Court of appeal, and the different date means that the offence expired [after the 10-year rule]. The prosecutor in the indictment also pointed out that "the delay of the final step in the ownership of the shares does not affect the time of when the expiry of the offence takes effect but stems from the desire of Mills to complicate the reconstruction of this illegal transfer of money and its origins" and that "when there is uncertainty about the date of committing an offence, the rule of favor rei applies: and the effect of the 10-year expiry must be fixed at the most favourable date for the accused ===Other controversies=== In 2001, Jowell was widely criticised for 'interfering' in [[Independent Television Commission]] (ITC) rulings on complaints regarding ''[[Brass Eye]]''. ''The Guardian'' newspaper suggested that "for the Culture Secretary to speak directly to the head of a TV network about a specific programme smacks of the Soviet commissar and the state broadcaster".{{cite news|title=Brass Eye was degrading: But the government is wrong to interfere|date=31 July 2001|work=The Guardian|location=London, UK|accessdate=25 May 2010|url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2001/jul/31/broadcasting.politics1|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140330211037/http://www.theguardian.com/media/2001/jul/31/broadcasting.politics1|archivedate=30 March 2014|deadurl=no}}{{cite news|title=TV spoof to bring tougher regulation|last=Ward|first=Lucy|date=30 July 2001|work=The Guardian|location=London, UK|url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2001/jul/30/broadcasting.politics|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090306182648/http://www.guardian.co.uk/media/2001/jul/30/broadcasting.politics|archivedate=6 March 2009|deadurl=no}}{{cite news|title=Programme causes predictable storm|date=30 July 2001|newspaper=BBC News|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/programmes/world_at_one/1465145.stm|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131005090006/http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/programmes/world_at_one/1465145.stm|archivedate=5 October 2013|deadurl=no}} The ITC reminded Jowell that she should not be interfering in their processes, resulting in a Channel Four interviewer suggesting Jowell and her colleagues "must feel like idiots".{{cite news|title=It was C4's most vetted programme. So how did it attract a record number of complaints|last=Jury|first=Louise|date=30 July 2001|newspaper=The Independent|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/media/it-was-c4s-most-vetted-programme-so-how-did-it-attract-a-record-number-of-complaints-679571.html|location=London, UK|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110908184252/http://www.independent.co.uk/news/media/it-was-c4s-most-vetted-programme-so-how-did-it-attract-a-record-number-of-complaints-679571.html|archivedate=8 September 2011|deadurl=no}} In 2006, Jowell was criticised{{cite web|url=http://www.morningstaronline.co.uk/a-3ece-Hypocrite-Jowell-given-peerage#.Vd-4njZRHIU|title=‘Hypocrite’ Jowell given peerage|first=People's Printing Press|last=Society|publisher=morningstaronline.co.uk|accessdate=13 May 2018}} for projected cost over-runs on the London [[2012 Summer Olympics]] project, which came under the supervision of her former department.{{cite news|title=Revealed: the true cost of Olympics|last=Campbell|first=Denis|date=19 November 2006|work=The Guardian|url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2006/nov/19/Olympics2012.olympics2012|location=London, UK|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090205191650/http://www.guardian.co.uk/uk/2006/nov/19/Olympics2012.olympics2012|archivedate=5 February 2009|deadurl=yes}} She was among a number of ministers accused of hypocrisy{{cite web|url=https://www.standard.co.uk/news/jowell-the-hypocrite-minister-backs-demo-to-save-post-office-despite-voting-in-parliament-for-its-6627028.html|title=Jowell the hypocrite: Minister backs demo to save post office despite|date=29 March 2008|publisher=standard.co.uk|accessdate=13 May 2018}} for opposing [[Post Office]] closures in their own constituencies while supporting the government's closure strategy at the national level.{{cite news|author2=Allegra Stratton|title=£1bn contract will save 3,000 post offices from closure|last=Wintour|first=Patrick|date=13 November 2008|work=The Guardian|location=London, UK|url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2008/nov/13/post-office-contract-closures-benefits|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090204054927/http://www.guardian.co.uk/uk/2008/nov/13/post-office-contract-closures-benefits|archivedate=4 February 2009|deadurl=yes}} Jowell was Secretary of State for Culture, Media and Sport during the [[News International phone hacking scandal|''News of the World'' newspaper phone-hacking scandal]] (pre-2007).{{cite news|work=BBC News Online|date=17 August 2011|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-11195407|title=Q&A: News of the World phone-hacking scandal|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100907195554/http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-11195407|archivedate=7 September 2010|deadurl=yes}} In January 2007, [[Clive Goodman]], the ''News of the World's'' 'royal editor', was jailed for four months, and [[Glenn Mulcaire]], a private investigator employed by the ''News of the World'', was jailed for six months.{{cite news|title=Pair jailed over royal voicemail-hacking|date=26 January 2007|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/6301243.stm|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140330212304/http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/6301243.stm|archivedate=30 March 2014|deadurl=no}} In May 2014 a temporary personal assistant to [[Richard Scudamore]], chief executive of England's [[Premier League]], read private emails between Scudamore and colleagues and friends. These included comments about women's football, which the assistant felt to be inappropriate. She passed them on to a national newspaper, the ''[[Daily Mirror]]''. Jowell defended the reading and passing-on of the emails, declaring that, "in the world of social media and email, there is no public and private".{{cite news|title=Richard Scudamore comments 'undermine women's game'|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/27361047|access-date=18 December 2014|work=BBC Sport|date=11 May 2014}} ==Leadership fellow== Jowell served as a Richard L. and Ronay A. Menschel Senior Leadership Fellow at [[Harvard T.H. Chan School of Public Health]] in 2016. In this role, she taught a course in the Department of Health Policy and Management called, "Health Policy and Leadership: Why do we know so much and do so little?"{{cite web |url=https://www.hsph.harvard.edu/policy-translation-leadership-development/senior-leadership-fellows-program/former-fellows/#tessajowell|title=Division of Policy Translation and Leadership Development> Senior Leadership Fellows Program> Past Fellows|accessdate=13 May 2018}} Jowell also actively served on the Advisory Board of the Ministerial Leadership in Health Program, a joint initiative of the Harvard T.H. Chan School of Public Health and the [[John F. Kennedy School of Government]].[https://ministerialleadership.harvard.edu/advisory-board Advisory Board], 17 January 2017; retrieved 4 April 2017. ==Personal life== Jowell's first marriage was to fellow [[London Borough of Camden|Camden Councillor]] [[Roger Jowell]] in 1970; this was dissolved in 1976, but she continued to use his [[surname]].{{cite news|work=tmc.net|title=The Minister And A £350,000 'Gift'|url=http://www.tmcnet.com/usubmit/2006/02/23/1402656.htm|date=23 February 2006}} Roger Jowell co-founded and directed Social & Community Planning Research (SCPR), now the National Centre for Social Research,{{cite web|title=NCCR|url=http://www.natcen.ac.uk|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090630013226/http://www.natcen.ac.uk|archivedate=30 June 2009|deadurl=yes}} known for its British Social Attitudes Surveys. She married [[David Mills (lawyer)|David Mills]] on 17 March 1979. They separated in March 2006, following the controversy over Mills's links to Berlusconi. Their professed hopes to "restore their relationship over time", rather than seek divorce, caused some to regard this as a politically expedient gesture to save her political career.{{cite news|title=Tessa Jowell splits from husband|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/4773468.stm|work=BBC News|date=4 March 2006|archivedate=21 October 2007|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071021085357/http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/4773468.stm|quote=The culture secretary and her husband are to separate after the 'strains' of allegations about their finances.|deadurl=yes}} Jowell said on [[BBC Radio 4|Radio 4]]'s ''[[Woman's Hour]]'' programme in September 2012 that she was seeing Mills regularly, saying that they had "reached a state of stability which I never thought possible". She had a son and daughter, as well as three stepchildren (including journalist [[Eleanor Mills (journalist)|Eleanor Mills]]) from her husband's first marriage.{{citation needed|date=May 2018}} In April 2016, her son Matthew Mills married food writer [[Ella Woodward]], who is also his business partner.{{cite news|author=Lexi Finnigan|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2016/04/25/deliciously-ella-ties-the-knot-on-the-tropical-island-of-mustiqu|title=Deliciously Ella ties the knot on the tropical island of Mustique|publisher=The Daily Telegraph|date=26 April 2016|accessdate=8 July 2016}}{{cite web|title=Entrepreneur of the Year Awards|url=http://www.ey.com/uk/en/about-us/entrepreneurship/entrepreneur-of-the-year/uk_eoy_home-winners-2017|website=ey.com|publisher=Ernst and Young|accessdate=27 July 2017}} Her daughter Jess Mills is a singer.{{cite news |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/music/news/can-you-guess-whose-daughter-this-is-6286300.html |title=Can you guess whose daughter this is? |first=Nick |last=Clark |work=The Independent |date=7 January 2012 |accessdate=13 May 2018}} In January 2011, during the [[News of the World phone hacking affair|''News of the World'' phone hacking affair]], it was revealed that Jowell had contacted [[lawyer]]s as she attempted to find out who hacked into her voicemails on 28 separate occasions during 2006. Jowell contacted [[police]] in late January 2011 to inform them that there had recently been an unsuccessful attempt to listen to voicemail messages on her phone.{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2011/jan/27/phoning-hacking-row-tessa-jowell|location=London, UK|work=The Guardian|title=Phone-hacking row escalates as Tessa Jowell speaks out|author=Nicholas Watt, James Robinson and Dan Sabbagh|date=27 January 2011|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110128051216/http://www.guardian.co.uk/media/2011/jan/27/phoning-hacking-row-tessa-jowell|archivedate=28 January 2011|deadurl=yes}} ===Illness and death=== On her 70th birthday on 17 September 2017, her family made public the news that she had been suffering from [[Brain tumor|brain cancer]] since May of that year. On her [[Twitter]] account, she stated "Thank you for so much love and support on my birthday. More people living longer better lives with cancer is my birthday pledge".{{Cite news|last=Revesz|first=Rachael|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/home-news/tessa-jowel-brain-cancer-family-reveals-70th-birthday-diagnosis-a7952176.html|title=Labour peer Tessa Jowell reveals battle with brain cancer after being diagnosed in May|work=The Independent|date=17 September 2017|accessdate=17 September 2017}} Jowell wanted more treatment for cancer patients, knowledge about cancer treatment shared more effectively, speedier diagnosis, greater access to experimental treatments, and improved survival rates.[https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2018/jan/26/tessa-jowell-cancer-treatment-britain Tessa Jowell is right about cancer treatment: Britain must do better], ''[[The Guardian]]''; accessed 13 May 2018. After Jowell's death, Downing Street announced that in tribute to her, brain cancer government funding would be doubled and the so-called "gold standard dye" tumour diagnosis tests would be extended to all NHS hospitals.{{Cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/science/2018/may/13/brain-cancer-to-get-more-funding-and-better-tests-says-no-10|title=Brain cancer to get more funding in tribute to Tessa Jowell, says No 10|last=Elgot|first=Jessica|date=2018-05-13|website=the Guardian|language=en|access-date=2018-05-14}} Jowell suffered a brain haemorrhage on 11 May 2018 and was in a coma until her death the following day at the age of 70.{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-44098760|title=Dame Tessa Jowell dies aged 70|date=13 May 2018|work=BBC News|access-date=13 May 2018}} ==Honours and styles== ===Honours=== *She was sworn of the [[Privy Council of the United Kingdom|Privy Council]] in 1998, giving her the honorific title "[[The Right Honourable]]" and, after ennoblement, the [[List of post-nominal letters (United Kingdom)|post-nominal letters]] "PC" for life. *[[File:Order of the British Empire (Civil) Ribbon.png|thumb|40px|Order of the British Empire (Civil) Ribbon]]She was appointed to the [[Order of the British Empire]] as a Dame Commander in the Civil Division in the [[2012 Birthday Honours]], giving her the right to the prenomial title "Dame" and [[List of post-nominal letters (United Kingdom)|post-nominal letters]] "DBE". However, the former, although hers was a substantive and not honorary damehood, was no longer practically applicable following her peerage, with its superseding form of address. * She was given the [[Freedom of the City|Freedom of the Borough]] of [[London Borough of Southwark|Southwark]] on 12 May 2012.{{cite news |url=https://news.sky.com/story/caine-is-southwark-freeman-10479056 |title=Caine is Southwark freeman |work=Sky News |date=13 May 2012 |accessdate=13 May 2018}}{{cite web|publisher=[[Flickr]]|title=The Freedom of the Borough of Southwark|url=https://www.flickr.com/photos/southwarkcouncil/sets/72157629724277788|accessdate=13 May 2018}} *[[File:Coronet of a British Baron.svg|thumb|40px|Coronet of a British Baron]]She was raised to the [[Peerage of the United Kingdom|peerage]] in the [[2015 Dissolution Honours]], allowing her to sit in the [[House of Lords]]. She sat with the [[Labour Party (UK)|Labour Party]] benches. She took the title of '''Baroness Jowell'''.{{cite web|publisher=GOV.UK|title=Dissolution Peerages 2015|url=https://www.gov.uk/government/news/dissolution-peerages-2015|accessdate=1 June 2016}} * On 17 June 2016 She was awarded the [[Honorary degree]] of [[Doctor of Laws]] (LL.D) by the [[University of Aberdeen]].{{cite web|url=https://www.abdn.ac.uk/news/9291/|title=University to present honorary degrees to distinguished individuals at Summer ceremonies - News - The University of Aberdeen|website=www.abdn.ac.uk}}{{cite web|url=https://www.abdn.ac.uk/graduation/honorary-graduates/summer-graduates-2016.php#the-rt-hon-the-baroness-jowell-dbe-pc-ma-lately-member-of-parliament|title=Summer Graduates - Graduation - The University of Aberdeen|website=www.abdn.ac.uk}} ===Styles of address=== *1947–1970: Ms Tessa Palmer *1970–1992: Ms Tessa Jowell *1992–1998: Ms Tessa Jowell {{post-nominals|country=GBR|MP}} *1998–2012: [[Privy Council of the United Kingdom|The Rt Hon]] Tessa Jowell {{post-nominals|country=GBR|MP}} *2012–2015: The Rt Hon [[Dame]] Tessa Jowell {{post-nominals|country=GBR|DBE|MP}} *2015: The Rt Hon Dame Tessa Jowell {{post-nominals|country=GBR|DBE}} *2015–2018: The Rt Hon The Baroness Jowell {{post-nominals|country=GBR|DBE|PC}} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== {{Commons category|Tessa Jowell}} *{{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150423002643/http://www.tessajowell.net |date=April 2015 |title=Official website}} *{{UK MP links |parliament=baroness-jowell/159 |hansard=ms-tessa-jowell |hansardcurr=1228 |guardian=2808/tessa-jowell |publicwhip=Tessa_Jowell |theywork=tessa_jowell |record=Tessa-Jowell/Dulwich-and-West-Norwood/254 |bbc=25526.stm |journalisted=tessa-jowell}} *[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/programmes/the_daily_politics/8617668.stm The Big Interview: Tessa Jowell], [[Andrew Neil]], ''[[BBC News]]'', 13 April 2010 {{s-start}} {{s-par|uk}} {{s-bef|before=[[Gerald Bowden]]}} {{s-ttl|title=[[Member of Parliament]]

{{Refimprove|date=September 2017}} {{Infobox medical condition (new) | name = Urogenital neoplasm | synonyms = | image = | caption = | pronounce = | field = | symptoms = | complications = | onset = | duration = | types = | causes = | risks = | diagnosis = | differential = | prevention = | treatment = | medication = | prognosis = | frequency = | deaths = }} A '''urogenital neoplasm''' is a tumor of the [[urogenital]] system.{{cite book|last1=Kurman|first1=Robert J.|title=Blaustein's Pathology of the Female Genital Tract|date=2013|publisher=Springer Science & Business Media|isbn=9781475738896|page=168|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=sM3eBwAAQBAJ&pg=PA168&dq=A+urogenital+neoplasm+is+a+tumor+of+the+urogenital+system.&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwidoIKA4qDWAhWDSSYKHfBqDG44FBDoAQglMAA#v=onepage&q=A%20urogenital%20neoplasm%20is%20a%20tumor%20of%20the%20urogenital%20system.&f=false|accessdate=12 September 2017|language=en}} Types include: * Cancer of the breast and female genital organs: ([[Breast cancer]], [[Vulvar cancer]], [[Vaginal cancer]], [[Vaginal tumors]], [[Cervical cancer]], [[Uterine cancer]], [[Endometrial cancer]], [[Ovarian cancer]]) * Cancer of the male genital organs ([[Carcinoma of the penis]], [[Prostate cancer]], [[Testicular cancer]]) * Cancer of the urinary organs ([[Renal cell carcinoma]], [[Bladder cancer]]) ==References== {{Reflist}} == External links == {{Medical resources | DiseasesDB = | ICD10 = {{ICD10|C|50||c|50}}-{{ICD10|C|68||c|64}}
